Having read the interview, I summarize Mr Meyer as follows, in three 
categories of statements.

  * TDD does not force us to consider /all/ cases, whereas DBC does
  * We get in trouble when we don't consider all test cases

  * It is possible to generate specific tests from generalized contract 
statements; whereas it is not possible (in general) to infer the 
generalized contract from specific tests
  * We ought to be generating specific tests from a generalized contract 
statement, rather than merely writing the specific tests

  * When performing TDD we ought to be choosing tests systematically

The last statement is by far the most important; so much so that it 
renders the remaining ones as mere implementation details.  When we 
choose the next test to write, we ought to do so /with a reason/. It's a 
little like playing chess: the ones who play it well play with a plan, 
and the ones who don't plan tend to lose. Where do we gain insight into 
good, systematic ways of choosing tests? We can read books like Software 
Testing Lessons Learned or we can spend time with a skilled QA person.

If we choose the next test with a reason, then when we practise TDD, we 
/will/ consider all the cases, even without DBC to force us to do so.

If we choose the next test with a reason, then when we practise TDD, we 
/will/ choose the appropriate set of specific tests for the generalized 
contract statement.

True, we won't be generating those tests from some other form, but 
/that's just an implementation detail/! So we needn't go nuts with the 
argument of TDD v. DBC. They are too different ways to do the same 
thing. When writing contracts a la DBC becomes as easy as writing JUnit 
tests, then I'm certainly willing to give it a try. Certainly we could 
mix the two approaches, writing contracts when it's easy to do so 
(because they can be more powerful and expressive) and writing JUnit 
tests the rest of the time.
